awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: East African Rift Tephra Database [EARThD]: a compilation documenting and analyzing explosive volcanism in East Africa
awd_abstract_narration:
The East African Rift Valley is home to hundreds of volcanoes that have produced large explosive eruptions in their past, sending volcanic ash into the atmosphere and dispersing it over large distances.  This volcanic ash (also called tephra) is deposited on land or in water bodies, and may become preserved in the geological record. Studies of tephra are important for a wide range of purposes including learning about the eruptive history of a volcano to anticipate potential future behavior, and correlating and dating rock layers for paleoanthropology and paleoclimatology studies. Traditionally, much of this work has been carried out by separate groups of researchers from these various disciplines, and a significant amount of data is then published in specialized literature, and hard to discover. A centralized database of tephra occurrence in East Africa would help overcome this barrier and encourage the use of existing valuable datasets, but also answer fundamental questions about the evolution of volcanism in East Africa through time. This project will address this need by building the East African Rift Tephra Database (EARThD), a comprehensive database that will integrate, standardize, and investigate geochemical and age tephra datasets from the East African Rift focusing on the record from the past 5 million years. 

The EARThD project will utilize the existing NSF-supported community-based data facility, Interdisciplinary Earth Data Alliance (IEDA), to store, curate, and provide access to geochemical data and metadata through IEDA's EarthChem library. Tephra samples from published articles will be assigned an International Sample Geo Number (IGSN) and associated datasets and metadata will be entered and formatted using standardized IEDA templates. The development of EARThD will fulfill the currently non-existent but crucial data integration and standardization effort needed to support the growing East African Rift tephra record and the increasingly complex and interdisciplinary research questions being studied. It will benefit a broad scientific community by encouraging and facilitating the cross-disciplinary use of tephra geochemical data and involve undergraduate student researchers. Results of this project will provide a clearer understanding of the temporal variations of explosive volcanism along the East African Rift, including the frequency and magnitude of past eruptions and long-term geochemical variations in response to continental rifting.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

East African sedimentary records containing tephra have typically been studied in isolation by researchers from different disciplines, and in most cases, there is very little cross-disciplinary communication. This makes it difficult to navigate through relevant literature and strongly limits the use of tephra deposits at their maximum potential.

In this project we compiled a comprehensive geochemical database of known tephra occurrence data across East Africa, drawn from the volcanological, geochemical, paleoanthropological, paleoclimatological and paleoenvironmental literature. The East African Rift Tephra Database (EARThD) compiled, integrated, standardized, and enhanced access to published scientific papers containing geochemical and geochronological data from tephra deposits collected in eastern Africa. Of particular importance to these efforts was prioritizing the availability and discoverability of data in alignment with current FAIR data reporting practices. The data was integrated into Interdisciplinary Earth Data Alliance (IEDA), a NSF-funded, open-access, and community-based data repository, providing a platform for cross-disciplinary studies utilizing new and existing tephra data. Our team included undergraduate and graduate students from Penn State University and Salem State University. We also worked with data managers and coders at IEDA to incorporate EARThD compiled datasets into the Petrologic Database (PetDB). Geochemical data from over 430 published scientific papers reporting on volcanic products were entered into EARThD and data from over 330 papers are currently available for download on the EarthChem website. The results of our work are tracked and data in PetDB is directly linked in our interactive map on the EARThD website.

Broader Impacts

In addition to the PIs, our team included sixteen undergraduate and two graduate students who were trained in data management, data mining, scientific paper comprehension, scientific poster and talk preparation and delivery, and in East African tephrochronology. Many of these students pursued careers in industry or have gone on to MS and PhD programs. We presented at national and international scientific meetings highlighting data mining, accessibility, and discoverability and chaired meeting sessions on tephrochronology. Three of our conference posters and talks were student led. In collaboration with IEDA, this project also facilitated the expansion of data accessibility through the introduction of refined queries and download capabilities to better serve the needs of the scientific community and the public.

In summer 2022, we developed and taught the Explosive Volcanism Educator Workshop for Pennsylvania K-12 educators at Penn State University Park. This 1-credit workshop was designed as an introductory volcanology short course to strengthen teachers knowledge of volcanology concepts, and to demonstrate how scientists collect and interpret real data from explosive deposits. Based on educator feedback, the workshop was highly successful and highlighted the need and demand for building connections between educators and scientists to strengthen STEM education in K-12 classrooms.
